dictionary.title: ipcc_ar6_wg3_man_dict
dictionary.desc: manually created by Chapter02: Abhishek Prasad(Date: 2022-08-23) , Chapter03: Sunag Parasu(Date: 2022-12-06),Chapter05: Karthikeyan V(Date: 2022-12-06), Chapter06: Mandeep(Date: 2022-11-19) Chapter07:kavita joshi(Date2022-08-23), Chapter08,17: Priti(Date: 2022-12-06)

entry.desc: limit on CO2 emission for a given climate impact

entry.name: fossil fuel combustion and industrial processes
forestry and other land-use
entry.desc: Greenhouse gas inventory sector that covers emissions and removals of greenhouse gases resulting from direct human-induced land use
man-made gases that can stay in the atmosphere for centuries and contribute to a global greenhouse effect
amount that must be paid for the right to emit one tonne of CO2 into the atmosphere

entry.name: Emissions Database for Global Atmospheric Research
entry.desc: a joint project of the European Commission Joint Research Centre and the Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency which estimates emissions of all greenhouse gases, air pollutants and aerosols

entry.name: Climate Analysis Indicators Tool
entry.desc: The Climate Analysis Indicators Tool (CAIT) is an information and data analysis tool on global climate change and provides a comprehensive and comparable database of greenhouse gas emissions data (including all major sources and sinks) and other climate-relevant indicators

entry.name: A Community Emissions Data System for Historical Emissions

entry.desc: An emissions factor is a representative value that attempts to relate the quantity of a pollutant released to the atmosphere with an activity associated with the release of that pollutant
An emission inventory (or emissions inventory) is an accounting of the amount of pollutants discharged into the atmosphere
Transportation, Industry, Agriculture, and Land Use and Forestry are four global emission sectors that roughly correspond to the U.S. sectors

entry.name: 100 year Global warming potential
entry.desc: Global warming potential calculated over a period of 100 years

entry.name: World Meteorological Organisation
entry.desc: specialised agency of the United Nations for meteorology

emissions inventory that comes from direct measurement and are done to evaluate measured emissions for a geographical region or sector, using measurements from hand-held OGC cameras, truck-mounted cameras, drones and planes, and satellites

entry.name: Global Temperature Change Potential
entry.desc: the change in global mean surface temperature at a chosen point in time in response to an emission pulse relative to that of CO2
rate used for discounting future benefits or costs to society

entry.name: Short Lived Climate Forcers
entry.desc: greenhouse gases and other climate pollutants that have relatively short atmospheric lifetimes compared to carbon dioxide

link.desc: Carbon dioxide equivalent or CO2e means the number of metric tons of CO2 emissions with the same global warming potential as one metric ton of another greenhouse gas

entry.desc: A projected development in time of the emission of a greenhouse gas or group of greenhouse gases, aerosols and greenhouse gas precursors.

entry.name: Food and Agriculture Organization Corporate Statistical Database
entry.desc: FAOSTAT website disseminates statistical data collected and maintained by the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO)

entry.name: Special Report on Emissions Scenarios
entry.desc: 2000 report by the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change

entry.name: Shared Socioeconomic Pathways
entry.desc: Over the past few years, an international team of climate scientists, economists and energy systems modellers have built a range of new “pathways” that examine how global society, demographics and economics might change over the next century. They are collectively known as SSPs
energy form not subjected to any human conversion process
direct use at the source, or supply to users without transformation, of crude energy, that is, energy that has not been subjected to any conversion or transformation process

link.desc: Baseline scenarios depict a future state of society and/or environment in which no new environmental policies are implemented apart from those already in the pipeline today; or in which these policies do not have a discernable influence regarding the questions being analysed

entry.desc: The atmospheric lifetime of a species measures the time required to restore equilibrium in the atmosphere following a sudden increase or decrease in concentration of the species in question in the atmosphere.

entry.name: Non-methane volatile organic compound
entry.desc: set of organic compounds that are typically photochemically reactive in the atmosphere and are marked by the exclusion of methane

Cumulative carbon dioxide (CO₂) emissions represents the total sum of CO₂ emissions produced from fossil fuels and cement since 1750, and is measured in tonnes. This measures CO₂ emissions from fossil fuels and cement production only – land use change is not included.
Final energy consumption covers all energy supplied to the final consumer for all energy uses. It is the sum of energy consumption in each final demand sector
anything that holds greenhouse gases from the atmosphere
A concept where past events or decisions constrain later events or decisions
To improve the quality of something
Emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs), precursors of GHGs and aerosols caused by human activities.
description of an event or series of actions and events
refers to the extent to which a material or system is composed of distinguishable pieces
the consequences of climate change
Climate model emulators are simple versions of climate models that only represent part of the system or represent the system at reduced complexity
Through its assessments, the IPCC determines the state of knowledge on climate change.
the process of establishing common laws, treaties and standards
the act of filling or closing gaps
running a climate model emulator
Energy intensity is a measure of the energy inefficiency of an economy
These pathways describe different climate futures, all of which are considered possible depending on the volume of greenhouse gases (GHG) emitted in the years to come
Greenhouse forcings occur due to changes in the level of gasses that share two properties: they are transparent to visible light, but absorb the infrared, which we typically perceive as heat
Some halogenated gases are considered major greenhouse gases due to their very high global warming potentials and long atmospheric lifetimes even if they only exist at a few ppt
GTP is an end-point metric that is based on temperature change for a selected year

The global damage potential (GDP) is expressed as the ratio of the social cost of a given greenhouse gas (GHG) to the social cost of CO2 (SCC), where the social cost of a GHG measures the (discounted) cumulative economic damage of that GHG
the state or degree of being easily or conveniently done
legislative policies related to climate change
technologies with low greenhouse gas emissions

entry.term: IPCC special report on global warming of 1.5C

entry.desc: teration is the repetition of a process in order to generate a (possibly unbounded) sequence of outcomes
data that provides information about other data
global CO2 emissions to fall below zero in the second half of this century, achieving what is known as net negative emissions
less extreme action
Climate projections are simulations of Earth's climate in future decades
Climate sensitivity is a measure of how much Earth's surface will cool or warm after a specified factor causes a change in its climate system
a baseline to compare alternative scenarios, or a starting point for analysis of a system
abatement potential is the term we use to describe the magnitude of potential GHG reductions which could be technologically and economically feasible to achieve
ozone gas found in the troposphere
emissions of tiny atmospheric particles of sea spray, smoke, dust, and other substances
Global warming potential is the heat absorbed by any greenhouse gas in the atmosphere, as a multiple of the heat that would be absorbed by the same mass of carbon dioxide

Transient climate response (TCR) is the mean global warming predicted to occur around the time of doubling CO2 in earth system model runs for which atmospheric CO2 concentration is prescribed to increase at 1 % per year
temperatures at the end of the century
a practice that enhance carbon sequestration in the soil or that mitigate the loss of soil carbon
Ocean alkalinization is an approach to carbon removal that involves adding alkaline substances to seawater to enhance the ocean's natural carbon sink
Bioenergy is a form of renewable energy generated when we burn biomass fuel
principles such as equality, capability and responsibility
intergovernmental report on climate change

entry.label: Avoid-Shift-Improve
entry.desc: approach to environmental sustainability by changing consumer behavior
Decent Living Standard

entry.label: greenhouse gases
entry.desc: gas in an atmosphere of a planet (usually Earth) that absorbs and emits radiation within the thermal infrared range and causes the greenhouse effect
statistical analysis of written publications, such as books or articles bibliometry
prevention of undesired coupling between subsystems
philosophical position that systems should be analyzed as wholes, not just as collections of parts
urban socioeconomic process
Nexus is a Latin word for connection, usually where multiple elements meet.
way of ranking available sources of energy
change of economy, especially of energy industries, towards lower carbon dioxide emissions
economy based on low carbon power sources
philosophy of pleasure as the highest value
belief in living 'the good life'

Gender-sensitive and multidimensional measure of poverty developed to assess deprivation at the individual level and overcome the limitations of current approaches which measure poverty at the household level.
Abundance of valuable financial assets or physical possessions which can be converted into a form that can be used for transactions.
process of extracting resources from the earth
the act of making something better; improvement
society where race is important
maximum energy available for use
trends that have an effect on a global scale. Some of the current megatrends are identicalwith global threats.

entry.desc: practice of operating transoceanic cargo ships, especially container ships, at significantly less than their maximum speed.
commercial service provided by commercial companies for cargo ships, to optimize their voyage performance.
two-propeller design for improving low-airspeed maneuverability
house that does not require fossil energy supply
less or no material is used to deliver the same level of functionality
group of components that deliver power to the driving wheels, excluding the part(s) which powers the machine
Net Zero Emission
academic journal published by AIMS Press, covering production of electric energy or power, powerplants, central stations
regenerative system in which resource input and waste, emission, and energy leakage, are minimised

entry.label: peer-to-peer
entry.desc: type of decentralized and distributed network architecture
Shared transport

entry.desc: use of integration of telecommunications and computers to access, store, transmit, and manipulate information

digital medium of exchange using cryptography on a ledger to secure transactions and to verify transfer of ownership
distributed data store for digital transactions
offers the use of a good or service rather than the good itself
flexible hours schedule that allows workers to alter workday start and finish times
merging of distinct identities or concepts, usually erroneously
carrying, free of charge, a transport company's own staff on a normal passenger trip
American transportation network company
peer-to-peer ridesharing, food delivery, and transportation network company headquartered in San Francisco, California
dockless bicycle sharing system

entry.label: life-cycle assessment
entry.desc: environmental assessment method
information assets characterized by such a high volume, velocity, and variety to require specific technology and analytical methods for its transformation into value
policy of constraining further development and population growth towithin the boundaries of preexisting urban areas rather than expanding outward into suburban areas

entry.label: circular economy
entry.desc: regenerative system in which resource input and waste, emission, and energy leakage, are minimised
biomimetic approach to the design of products
imitation of biological systems for the solving of human problems
Netherlands Environmental Assessment Agency
A participant who enters something, such as a contest.

having knowledge or awareness
principle or practice of concern for the welfare of others
trend of thought that favors equality for all people
measure of statistical dispersion

entry.name: sustainable development goals
entry.desc: set of United Nations-defined global development goals and climate change
fuel that is produced through contemporary biological processes, as opposed to fossil fuel that was produced by prehistoric bio-geological processes
is the ability of a thing (a living organism, an artificial system, an idea, etc.) to maintain itself or recover its potentialities.
zero net energy consumption
power produced with lower carbon dioxide emissions
system to generate, transmit and distribute electricity
significant bottleneck in the supply of energy resources to an economy
national security considerations of energy availability
introduction of contaminants into the natural environment that cause adverse change

reducing energy consumption
fuel formed by natural processes such as anaerobic decomposition of buried dead organisms
increase in global average temperature
changing of one form to another
Greenhouse gas emissions from human activities strengthen the greenhouse effect, causing climate change. Most is carbon dioxide from burning fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas

entry.name: human development index
entry.desc: composite statistic of life expectancy, education, and income indices

International Energy Agency
entry.desc: intergovernmental organization

entry.name: Concentrated solar power
entry.desc: large-scale solar thermal system using concentrated sunlight

entry.name: Direct air capture
entry.desc: method of carbon capture from carbon dioxide in air

entry.name: Carbon dioxide removal
entry.desc: removal of atmospheric carbon dioxide
refinery that converts biomass to energy and useful byproducts
storage of heat or cold for periods of up to several months
radiant light and heat from the Sun that is harnessed using a range of technologies
fuel that is produced through contemporary biological processes, as opposed to fossil fuel that was produced by prehistoric bio-geological processes
global sum of all ecosystems
where the captured carbon dioxide is used
current rise in Earth's average temperature and related large-scale shifts in weather patterns
combustible sedimentary rock composed primarily of carbon
process of getting coal out of the ground
removal of forest and conversion of the land to non-forest use
solid material that can be burnt to release energy
technique that uses a direct electric current to drive an otherwise non-spontaneous chemical reaction
any liquid fuel specifically designed for use in a diesel engine
electricity generated by hydropower
biological material used as a renewable energy source
power generated from nuclear reactions
any material that stores energy that can later be extracted, in presence of a oxidizer or a catalyser, or under the effect of a tool, but which is not conserved after the reaction
methods of energy production from various sources
petroleum-derived liquid used primarily as a fuel
anthropogenic may also refer to things that have been generated by humans
natural reservoir that stores carbon-containing chemical compounds accumulated over an indefinite period of time

entry.name: integrated assessment models
entry.desc: term used for a type of scientific modelling that tries to link main features of society and economy with the biosphere and atmosphere into one modelling framework.

entry.name: Bioenergy with carbon capture and storage
entry.desc: removing carbon dioxide from the atmosphere by growing plants, and then putting it permanently underground
preserved remains or traces of organisms from a past geological age

entry.name: Nationally Determined Contributions
entry.desc: non-binding national plans highlighting climate actions
energy from renewable biological sources.

entry.name: Agroecology
entry.desc: study of ecological processes in agriculture

entry.name: Land Use, Land-Use Change, and Forestry
entry.wikipediaPage: greenhouse gas inventory sector that covers emissions and removals of greenhouse gases resulting from direct human-induced land use such as settlements and commercial uses, land-use change, and forestry activities.

entry.name: Global Fire Emission Database
entry.desc: provides monthly burned area, fire carbon (C) and dry matter (DM) emissions, and the contribution of different fire types to these emissions in order to calculate trace gas and aerosol emissions using emission factors.

entry.name: Potsdam Real-Time Integrated Model for the probabilistic Assessment of Emission Pathways.
entry.desc: The PRIMAP-hist dataset combines several published datasets to create a comprehensive set of greenhouse gas emission pathways for every country

entry.name: National Greenhouse Gas Inventories
entry.desc: emission inventories of greenhouse gas emissions that are developed for a variety of reasons

entry.name: Global Warming Potential
entry.desc: Estimate of how an atmospheric gas affects global climate change

entry.name: Dynamic global vegetation model
entry.desc: a computer program that simulates shifts in potential vegetation and its associated biogeochemical and hydrological cycles as a response to shifts in climate.

entry.name: Land-Use Harmonization
entry.desc: project, with the goal to smoothly connect updated historical reconstructions of land-use with new future projections in the format required for ESMs
Fertilization from from increased levels of atmospheric carbon dioxide
establishment of a forest or stand of trees in an area where there was no previous tree cover

entry.name: Global Carbon Project
entry.desc: The Global Carbon Project (GCP) is an organisation that seeks to quantify global greenhouse gas emissions and their causes

entry.name: Global Forest Resources Assessment
entry.desc: The Global Forest Resources Assessment (FRA) reports on the status and trends of the world's forest resources

the maximum amount of cumulative net global anthropogenic carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions that would result in limiting global warming to a given level with a given probability, taking into account the effect of other anthropogenic climate forcers

entry.name: United States Environmental Protection Agency
entry.desc: an independent executive agency of the United States federal government tasked with environmental protection matters

entry.name: Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development
entry.desc: an international organisation of those developed countries that accept the principles of representative democracy and a free market economy
a shrub or tree that grows in coastal saline or brackish water
the variety and variability of life on Earth. Biodiversity is a measure of variation at the genetic (genetic variability), species (species diversity), and ecosystem (ecosystem diversity) level
forested landscapes in tropical regions: i.e. land areas approximately bounded by the tropic of Cancer and Capricorn

entry.name: Environmental Impact Assessments
entry.desc: assessment of the environmental consequences of a plan, policy, program, or actual projects prior to the decision to move forward with the proposed action

entry.name: UN Environment Programme
entry.desc: responsible for coordinating responses to environmental issues within the United Nations system

entry.name: Climate smart agriculture
entry.desc: an integrated approach to managing landscapes to help adapt agricultural methods, livestock and crops to the effects of climate change and, where possible, counteract it by reducing greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture, at the same time taking into account the growing world population to ensure food security

entry.name: Secretariat of the Convention on Biological Diversity

entry.desc: acquisition of information about an object or phenomenon without making physical contact with the object, especially the Earth
introduced organism that becomes overpopulated and harms its new environment
a biogeographic region that is both a significant reservoir of biodiversity and is threatened with destruction
distinct biological communities that have formed in response to a shared physical climate

entry.name: EU Renewable Energy Directive
entry.desc: Directive 2001/77/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council of 27 September 2001 on the promotion of electricity produced from renewable energy sources in the internal electricity market

entry.name: Plan for Prevention and Control of Deforestation in the Legal Amazon
entry.desc: Plan for Prevention and Control of Deforestation in the Amazon (PPCDAM), with the goal to reduce the rate of restation through land use regulation, environmental monitoring, and sustainable activities, promoted through partnerships at the federal and private level, and legal penalties for violations

entry.name: Regenerative Agriculture
entry.desc: a conservation and rehabilitation approach to food and farming systems
an agricultural system that uses fertilizers of organic origin such as compost manure, green manure, and bone meal and places emphasis on techniques such as crop rotation and companion planting

entry.name: Conservation Agriculture
entry.desc: A farming system that promotes minimum soil disturbance (i.e. no-till farming), maintenance of a permanent soil cover, and diversification of plant species

entry.name: Business as Usual scenario
entry.desc: the normal execution of standard functional operations within an organisation, forms a possible contrast to projects or programmes which might introduce change
are crops with high yield of lignocellulosic biomass produced to serve as a raw material for production of second generation biofuel

entry.name: Co-existence of Agriculture and Nature: Optimisation and Planning of Integrated Ecosystem Services

entry.desc: a digestive process by which carbohydrates are broken down by microorganisms into simple molecules for absorption into the bloodstream of an animal. Because of human agricultural reliance in many parts of the world on animals which digest by enteric fermentation, it is one of the factors in increased methane emissions.
Biochar is the lightweight black residue, made of carbon and ashes, remaining after the pyrolysis of biomas

long term population movements (shift) from rural to urban areas;gradual increase in the proportion of people living in urban areas, and the ways in which each society adapts to the change;process by which towns and cities are formed and become larger
Mitigation is the reduction of something harmful or the reduction of its harmful effects
energy that is collected from renewable sources
process of converting a device, process, or society to the use of electric power
Carbon lock-in refers to the self-perpetuating inertia created by large fossil fuel-based energy systems that inhibits public and private efforts to introduce alternative energy technologies

technique for physical organisation of space

the classification of characteristics common to buildings or urban spaces

an official designation for a certain type of urban locality used in some of the republics of Africa such as Southern Africa

total domestic and foreign output claimed by residents of a country, consisting of gross domestic product, plus factor incomes earned by foreign residents, minus income earned in the domestic economy by nonresidents

Urban metabolism is a model to facilitate the description and analysis of the flows of the materials and energy within cities, such as undertaken in a material flow analysis of a city

entry.name: Water-sensitive urban design
entry.desc: (WSUD) is a land planning and engineering design approach which integrates the urban water cycle, including stormwater, groundwater, and wastewater management and water supply, into urban design to minimise environmental degradation and improve aesthetic and recreational appeal.
